title: How to Fix Scratches on a PSP Screen

steps.headline: Basically, all you would need to do is sand down the surface.
steps.description: The technique used is: start with a high grade sandpaper and work your way down to fine sanding liquid until you can no longer see scratches.

steps.headline: It is highly recommended, before starting to sand, that you remove the outer screen by taking out the set of tiny screws in the back.
steps.description: This is very easy and will make it much easier to deal with this process.

steps.headline: Start with a grade of sandpaper that makes scratches of about the same depth of the scratch(s) you already have in the screen (test with plexiglass; see "Warning" below).
Sand in circles on the exact area to be fixed.
steps.description: -Here it is suggested to put masking tape all over the casing where you don't want to sand so as to protect it.- Do this until the sanded area looks uniform.

steps.headline: Clean the surface and your hands thoroughly.
steps.description: Do not intermix the sandpaper particles as this will defeat your progress.

steps.headline: Next, go the next grade of sandpaper down and sand in the same area as before.
steps.description: Do this until the sanded area looks uniform.

steps.headline: Clean the surface and your hands thoroughly.
steps.description: Do not intermix the sandpaper particles as this will defeat your progress.

steps.headline: Repeat the last 2 steps over and over, going down to the next finest grade each time until you reach the liquid grades.
If you've done it right, you will not be able to see scratches any longer.
steps.description: Even if you only see some improvement, you are on the right track. You may need to repeat this process, but starting from the grade of sandpaper closest to the scratches you have left (sometimes a heavier grade, sometimes a lighter grade than what you started with) See tips & warning.

text: Basically, all you would need to do is sand down the surface. The technique used is: start with a high grade sandpaper and work your way down to fine sanding liquid until you can no longer see scratches. It is highly recommended, before starting to sand, that you remove the outer screen by taking out the set of tiny screws in the back. This is very easy and will make it much easier to deal with this process. Start with a grade of sandpaper that makes scratches of about the same depth of the scratch(s) you already have in the screen (test with plexiglass; see "Warning" below).  Sand in circles on the exact area to be fixed. -Here it is suggested to put masking tape all over the casing where you don't want to sand so as to protect it.- Do this until the sanded area looks uniform. Clean the surface and your hands thoroughly. Do not intermix the sandpaper particles as this will defeat your progress. Next, go the next grade of sandpaper down and sand in the same area as before. Do this until the sanded area looks uniform. Clean the surface and your hands thoroughly. Do not intermix the sandpaper particles as this will defeat your progress. Repeat the last 2 steps over and over, going down to the next finest grade each time until you reach the liquid grades.  If you've done it right, you will not be able to see scratches any longer. Even if you only see some improvement, you are on the right track. You may need to repeat this process, but starting from the grade of sandpaper closest to the scratches you have left (sometimes a heavier grade, sometimes a lighter grade than what you started with) See tips & warning.
